articles.headline: Why Is Amazon in Entertainment?
articles.snippet: Amazon will buy MGM. Cool. But why does the tech giant have a streaming video service at all?
articles.abstract: Amazon will buy MGM. Cool. But why does the tech giant have a streaming video service at all?
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

articles.headline: A Culture of Fear at the Firm That Manages Bill Gates’s Fortune
articles.snippet: At least four employees at the firm, Cascade Investment, complained to Mr. Gates about Michael Larson, his longtime money manager.
articles.abstract: At least four employees at the firm, Cascade Investment, complained to Mr. Gates about Michael Larson, his longtime money manager.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 27 years, Bill Gates has entrusted the management of his enormous wealth and the endowment of his giant foundation to a single man: Michael Larson.
articles.byline: By Anupreeta Das, Emily Flitter and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: U.S. Faces Outbreak of Anti-Semitic Threats and Violence
articles.snippet: In the wake of clashes in Israel and Gaza, synagogues have been vandalized and Jews have been threatened and attacked.
articles.abstract: In the wake of clashes in Israel and Gaza, synagogues have been vandalized and Jews have been threatened and attacked.
articles.lead_paragraph: A brick shattering a window of a kosher pizzeria on Manhattan’s Upper East Side. Jewish diners outside a sushi restaurant in Los Angeles attacked by men shouting anti-Semitic threats. Vandalism at synagogues in Arizona, Illinois and New York.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Liam Stack

articles.headline: Biden Orders Intelligence Inquiry Into Origins of Virus
articles.snippet: The directive came as health officials and scientists have renewed calls for a more rigorous examination.
articles.abstract: The directive came as health officials and scientists have renewed calls for a more rigorous examination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden ordered U.S. intelligence agencies on Wednesday to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, indicating that his administration takes seriously the possibility that the deadly virus was accidentally leaked from a lab, in addition to the prevailing theory that it was transmitted by an animal to humans outside a lab.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Julian E. Barnes, Carl Zimmer and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: Gunman Kills 9 People at San Jose Rail Yard
articles.snippet: The gunman, who apparently killed himself, was an employee of the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, a regional transit agency for Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: The gunman, who apparently killed himself, was an employee of the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, a regional transit agency for Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A municipal transit worker opened fire as the Wednesday morning shift was gathering for work at a San Jose rail yard, killing nine people in the latest of the mass shootings that have plagued the United States this year.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Shawn Hubler and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Twitter Calls on Indian Government to Respect Free Speech
articles.snippet: After the government targeted posts criticizing its response to the coronavirus spread, Twitter said it would push back on what it called “intimidation tactics.”
articles.abstract: After the government targeted posts criticizing its response to the coronavirus spread, Twitter said it would push back on what it called “intimidation tactics.”
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Twitter pushed back on Thursday against India’s increasingly heavy-handed efforts to control online speech, calling on the government to respect freedom of expression and criticizing what it called “intimidation tactics” by the country’s police.

articles.headline: A Wave of Afghan Surrenders to the Taliban Picks Up Speed
articles.snippet: Dozens of besieged outposts or bases, and four district centers, have given up to the insurgents this month, in an accelerating rural collapse as American troops leave.
articles.abstract: Dozens of besieged outposts or bases, and four district centers, have given up to the insurgents this month, in an accelerating rural collapse as American troops leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEHTARLAM, Afghanistan — Ammunition was depleted inside the bedraggled outposts in Laghman Province. Food was scarce. Some police officers hadn’t been paid in five months.
articles.byline: By David Zucchino and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Why Apple and Google’s Virus Alert Apps Had Limited Success
articles.snippet: The virus-tracing effort raises questions about the power of Big Tech to set global standards for public health tools.
articles.abstract: The virus-tracing effort raises questions about the power of Big Tech to set global standards for public health tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sarah Cavey, a real estate agent in Denver, was thrilled last fall when Colorado introduced an app to warn people of possible coronavirus exposures.

articles.headline: A Temporary U.S.-China Trade Truce Starts to Look Durable
articles.snippet: Last year’s deal could set the rules for global commerce for years to come, leaving the door open to lavish Chinese subsidies and unilateral American tariffs.
articles.abstract: Last year’s deal could set the rules for global commerce for years to come, leaving the door open to lavish Chinese subsidies and unilateral American tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Just days before the coronavirus shut down the Chinese city of Wuhan and changed the world, the Trump administration and China signed what both sides said would be only a temporary truce in their 18-month trade war.

articles.headline: Hong Kong Has a New Type of Prisoner: Pro-Democracy Activists
articles.snippet: Hundreds of protesters, many students or college-educated, face potentially stiff sentences after Beijing’s crackdown. Those behind bars already battle isolation and disillusionment.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of protesters, many students or college-educated, face potentially stiff sentences after Beijing’s crackdown. Those behind bars already battle isolation and disillusionment.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A half year after he got out of prison, Daniel Tang has made a habit of going back. He waits in spare, crowded corridors. He greets familiar faces among the fellow visitors and guards. He brings books, postage stamps, writing paper and packets of M&Ms.
articles.byline: By Tiffany May and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Goodbye to a Yankee Farmer, the Ghost of Exit 8
articles.snippet: In 1964, a Vermont farmer burned himself and his farm, rather than surrender his land. His neighbors can’t let him go.
articles.abstract: In 1964, a Vermont farmer burned himself and his farm, rather than surrender his land. His neighbors can’t let him go.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEATHERSFIELD, Vt. — The morning sun was just slanting through the trees when a crew arrived with chain saws to remove the last sign of Romaine Tenney.

articles.headline: In Rwanda, Macron Tries to Reset Relations With Africa
articles.snippet: The visit by President Emmanuel Macron of France, and his recognition of the part played by his country in Rwanda’s genocide, reflected his efforts to find friends and potential business partners in Africa.
articles.abstract: The visit by President Emmanuel Macron of France, and his recognition of the part played by his country in Rwanda’s genocide, reflected his efforts to find friends and potential business partners in Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — After nearly three decades of recriminations over France’s role in Rwanda’s genocide of 1994, the leaders of the two countries on Thursday stood side by side in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, declaring a new chapter in their relations.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Abdi Latif Dahir

articles.headline: Biden to Propose $6 Trillion Budget to Make U.S. More Competitive
articles.snippet: The president’s plans to invest in infrastructure, education, health care and more would push federal spending to its highest sustained levels since World War II.
articles.abstract: The president’s plans to invest in infrastructure, education, health care and more would push federal spending to its highest sustained levels since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will propose a $6 trillion budget on Friday that would take the United States to its highest sustained levels of federal spending since World War II as he looks to fund a sweeping economic agenda that includes large new investments in education, transportation and fighting climate change.
